revision.text:
[[File:Aarón Sáenz Garza and family aboard ship in 1922.jpg|thumb|Aarón Sáenz Garza and family aboard ship in 1922]] '''Aarón Sáenz Garza''' (1 June 1891 – 26 February 1983) was a Mexican politician.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=wThaAAAAYAAJ&q=Aarón+Sáenz+Garza+1983&dq=Aarón+Sáenz+Garza+1983&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiP4IuoutvXAhWE2KQKHRObBgYQ6AEIMDAC Profile of Aarón Sáenz Garza]</ref>
==Biography== He was born in [[Monterrey]], [[Nuevo León]].
Sáenz Garza served as [[Secretary of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)|Secretary of Foreign Affairs]] during Calles' time as president. During his tenure, he continuously defended the Calles Administration's decision to cut oil to the United States when US Secretary of State Frank Kellog tried to bargain for a deal.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,722820,00.html |title=MEXICO: Vexful Waiting |work=Time |date=1926-12-06 |accessdate=2013-03-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,846094,00.html |title=Foreign News: Secrets |work=Time |date=1927-03-14 |accessdate=2013-03-12}}</ref> He soon became [[Governor of Nuevo León]] and maintained close ties with Calles; as governor, he even sat with Calles when he questioned the assassin of President-elect Alvaro Obregon in 1928.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,786965,00.html |title=MEXICO: Must keep calm! |work=Time |date=1928-07-30 |accessdate=2013-03-12}}</ref> It was also announced that Calles had plans to nominate him as the Chairman of the National Revolutionary Party.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,928342-2,00.html |title=MEXICO: New President |work=Time |date=1928-12-10 |accessdate=2013-03-12}}</ref> [[President of Mexico|President]] [[Pascual Ortiz Rubio]] appointed him [[Secretary of Education (Mexico)|Secretary of Public Education]] on February 1930. By 1934, Saenz had been dubbed as the "Shadow of Calles" and was named Governor of Mexico's Federal District by Mexican President [[Lázaro Cárdenas]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,748144,00.html |title=MEXICO: Palm Down |work=Time |date=1934-12-10 |accessdate=2013-03-12}}</ref> Cardenas and the Mexican Congress, however, soon turned on both Calles and Saenz and condemned their continued persecution against Catholics in the country.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,788523-2,00.html |title=MEXICO: Ossy, Ossy, Boneheads |work=Time |date=1935-02-04 |accessdate=2013-03-12}}</ref>
After leaving office in 1935, Saenz established a sugar corporation and quickly revolutionized sugar production in the country.<ref>Aarón Sáenz; Mexico's revolutionary capitalist, James C. Hefley, pg. 93</ref> He was also known as the "king of Mexican sugar", founding a dynasty which survives until this date, led by his son Aaron Saenz Couret and grandson Aaron Saenz Hirschfeld, at the head of the leading sugar company in Mexico. At one point, he held a virtual monopoly of Mexico's sugar industry.<ref name=ipm>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,858259-5,00.html |title=MEXICO: The Domino Player |work=Time |date=1953-09-14 |accessdate=2013-03-12}}</ref> His monopoly, however, was brought down during the administration of Mexican president [[Adolfo Ruiz Cortines]] by 1953.<ref name=ipm /> Saenz was married to Margarita Couret, with whom he had eight sons.
He died on 26 February 1983.
==Businesses== For some time they all managed varied branches of the family's businesses, most of which have ceased to exist or passed into others' ownership. Most notable among these were:
*[[Mexicana de Aviación]] (Now bankrupt) *Sugar mills *Seguros Atlas—merged with Seguros Comercial America in the 90's and afterwards sold to France's [[AXA]] *Banca Confía—nationalized in 1982, only to be re privatized by [[Carlos Salinas de Gortari]]'s administration and passing into the hands of [[Jorge Lankenau]]'s insurance group, later to be merged with [[Grupo Financiero Banamex|Banamex]] and acquired by [[Citibank]] during President [[Ernesto Zedillo]]'s administration.
==Legacy== Aarón Sáenz was related to [[Raul Saenz]], a prominent Mexican businessman in [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]] state, as well as [[Moises Saenz]], a prominent Mexican educator and diplomat.
